reviewText: Clarence Brown's 1935 version of 'Ah, Wilderness!,' while at moments overdone in its sentimentality, is a fine adaptation of O'Neill's heartwarming play (a modifier it's difficult to reconcile being applied to the work of one of America's most unrelentingly depressive literary geniuses).  Lionel Barrymore and Wallace Beery are excellent and the screenplay takes only a few liberties with the source material.  Warner Archive's no-frills DVD-R isn't restored to any commendable degree, with all kinds of age-related debris on display from the first frame to the last, but the audio is clear and the picture is reasonably sharp.  Movie earns 4-minus stars, presentation 3-plus.  For comparison, try Broadway Theatre Archives' first-rate 1976 teleplay (4 1/2 stars) available from Image Entertainment.

reviewText: "Ah Wilderness" is a 1935 adaptation of the Nobel Laureate Eugene O'Neill 1933 play of the same name. This was O'Neill's only comedy and most of his works have a much darker edge (e.g., "Long Day's Journey Into Night", "The Iceman Cometh"). Directed by Clarence Brown, the film stars Wallace Beery and Lionel Barrymore, but most of the action revolves around Eric Linden who plays Barrymore's son. Other members of the excellent cast include Spring Byington, Charley Grapewin, Frank Albertson, Aline MacMahon, and a young Mickey Rooney.The play was a slice of life in a small New England town in 1906 and the focus was on the father. For the screen, the son's life was expanded as was the role of the brother-in-law, but it remains essentially the same - a coming of age for a young boy and a nostaglic look back at a simpler way of life.The great Lionel Barrymore (1878-1954) plays the patriarch of a large family in a small New England town. Barrymore appeared in more than 200 films between 1908 and 1956, and was twice nominated for an Oscar, winning once ("A Free Soul" ) in 1931 He's probably best known as the evil banker in "It's a Wonderful Life" (1946) and from his recurring roles in the Dr. Kildare and the Dr. Gillepsie films.Spring Byington (1886-1971) plays Barrymore's wife. She was nominated for an Oscar for "You Can't Take it with you" (1938) and twice for an Emmy for her work in "December Bride" (1954-9).Wallace Beery (1885-1949) plays Barrymore's drunken brother-in law. Beery was one of the biggest villains in the silent era. His work in 1930 ("Big House", "Min and Bill", "Billy the Kid") followed by the best actor award in 1931 for "The Champ" elevated Beery to the A list where he remained and made such memorable films as "Treasure Island" (1934), "Viva Villa" (1934), and "China Seas" (1935).Aline MacMahon (1899-1991) plays Beery's love interest. MacMahon was known for her wise cracking demeanor and was popular in the 30s and 40s and nominated for an Oscar as the Chinese mother of Katherine Hepburn in "Dragon Seed" (1944).Eric Linden (1909-94) plays Barrymore's middle son. He was popular in the 30s as a supporting actor in films like "The Crowd Roars" (1932) and "Sweepings" (1933), but he never made a successful transition to adult roles.Frank Albertson (1909-1964) plays Barrymore's eldest son, home from Yale. Albertson appeared in more than 100 films and TV shows. He gave memorable performances in "The Last Hurrah" (1958), "The Enemy Below" (1957), and "It's a Wonderful Life" (1946).Charley Grapewin (1869-1956) plays the father of Linden's girlfriend. He made over 100 films between 1900 and 1951 and is probably best remembered as Uncle Henry from "The Wizard of Oz" (1939) and Grandpa Joad in "The Grapes of Wrath" (1940).Mickey Rooney (1920) is arguably one of the two greatest entertainers of the 20th Century. He had great commercial and critical success in two different series - "Mickey McGuire" (60+ shorts from 1927-34) and "Andy Hardy" (16 films from 1937-58) - which is a feat rarely equaled in Hollywood history. Apart from his phenomenal success with his series, Mickey had a third career as a song and dance man, often paired with his good friend Judy Garland (1922-69) in films like "Thoroughbreds Don't Cry" (1937) and Oscar nominated "Babes in Arms" (1939).Clarence Brown (1890 - 1987) directs. Brown was a well known silent film director ("Last of the Mohicans", "The Eagle"). He was nominated for an Oscar 5 times ("Anna Christie", "A Free Soul", "The Human Comedy", "National Velvet", and "The Yearling") but never won. His films earned 38 Oscar nominations and 9 wins, but never for Director.1935 was a good year for films."Mutiny on the Bounty" and "The Informer" were box office and Oscar winners. Other top 10 grossing films included Gable and Harlow in "China Seas", Flynn and de Havilland in "Captain Blood", Shirley Temple in "The Littlest Rebel" and "Curly Top", and Greta Garbo in "Anna Karenina". Other notable films released that year included "Alice Adams" with Hepburn, "The 39 Steps", "The Bride of Frankenstein", "David Copperfield", "A Tale of Two Cities", "Les Miserables", "Top Hat", and "A Night at the Opera". In Germany, Leni Riefenstahl released "Triumph of the Will".The New York Times called the film a "warm, sprawling and achingly reminiscent mood of story-telling" and praised the acting.Bottom line - a sentimental look back at turn of the century small town life.

reviewText: This movie was based on a very popular book by Eugene O[Neill.  It is a story about a turn-of-the century New England family, and has a top-notch cast.  Today's generation probably won't recognize the "stars," since Mickey Rooney was a very young child at the time.  Family values were important, and the father was "head of the house."  It's simple and sweet, and there is a hilarious scene at the dinner table that still makes me laugh.  Highly recommended for classic collectors.
